command.headquarters_location: Tunisia - Mobile HQ following First Army advance

M4A2 Sherman.note: Primary medium tank, re-equipped after Kasserine

Crusader III.note: Being phased out, used for reconnaissance and support roles

supply_logistics.supply_status: Adequate for offensive operations. Primary challenge: long supply lines from Algerian ports (800-1000km). Fuel and ammunition prioritized for armoured operations. Water supply critical in desert terrain. First Army logistics significantly better than 8th Army's extended lines from Egypt.

weather_environment.terrain_type: Mixed: Coastal hills and valleys (northern Tunisia), some desert approaches, agricultural areas, fortified defensive positions

tactical_doctrine.role: Mobile armoured exploitation and breakthrough operations in Tunisia Campaign
special_capabilities: Combined arms coordination (tanks, motorized infantry, artillery)
Experience integrating with US II Corps operations
tactical_innovations: Adapted to mixed terrain (not pure desert warfare)
Coordination with First Army's multi-national composition
Integration of Sherman tanks after Kasserine lessons
known_issues: Limited combat experience before Tunisia (formed 1940, first major action 1943)
Logistics challenges with extended supply lines
Tank reliability issues in rugged terrain
tactical_doctrine.desert_adaptations: Division adapted to Mediterranean coastal environment rather than pure desert. Emphasis on mobility and exploitation in broken terrain.

scenario_suitability: Tunisia Campaign battles (Fondouk, El Kourzia, Tunis assault)
special_rules: First major campaign - steady but not veteran
Sherman tanks improve anti-tank capability vs earlier Crusaders

source: Quartermaster Section - 6th Armoured Division organization and commanders
Web search: British armoured division organization 1943
Web search: 6th Armoured Division Tunisia operations
Schema v3.1.0: British armoured division standard structure

chief_of_staff.mitigation: Check British Army Lists 1943-Q2 for staff appointments

detailed_brigade_compositions.reason: Regiment names known but not detailed TO&E
detailed_brigade_compositions.estimate_method: Used standard British armoured brigade structure (3 regiments per armoured brigade, 3 battalions per infantry brigade)
detailed_brigade_compositions.mitigation: Extract subordinate brigade and regiment TO&Es separately

exact_tank_quantities_by_regiment.reason: Division-level totals available, regiment breakdown calculated
sources_checked: Web search: British armoured division tank establishment 1943
Historical records: Sherman re-equipment after Kasserine
exact_tank_quantities_by_regiment.estimate_method: Applied standard British armoured regiment establishment (52 tanks per regiment x 3 regiments = 156 cruisers, plus reconnaissance and reserve tanks)
exact_tank_quantities_by_regiment.mitigation: Consult unit war diaries or Nafziger OOB for specific dates

nco_count.reason: Total personnel known, NCO count calculated from standard ratios
nco_count.estimate_method: Applied 12.5% NCO ratio standard for British armoured divisions
nco_count.mitigation: Low priority - ratio is consistent across British formations

individual_artillery_regiment_designatio.reason: Number of regiments and gun types known, specific regiment numbers/names not confirmed
sources_checked: Web search: British armoured division artillery 1943
individual_artillery_regiment_designatio.estimate_method: Used standard 1943 British armoured division artillery: 2x field regiments (25-pdr), 1x anti-tank regiment, 1x LAA battery
individual_artillery_regiment_designatio.mitigation: Check divisional war diaries or artillery unit histories

exact_support_vehicle_breakdown.reason: Total vehicles calculated, specific variant counts estimated from standard establishments
exact_support_vehicle_breakdown.estimate_method: Applied standard British division transport allocation ratios
